questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cyanotic congenital heart disease?
questions.solution:
The most common cyanotic congenital heart disease is tetralogy of Fallot (ToF).

Infants are often asymptomatic until later in life (beyond 1yr of life).

TOF has 4 components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • ToF: Most common cyanotic CHD in the entire population
  • TGA (Transposition of Great Arteries) : Most common cyanotic CHD to manifest with cyanosis in a newborn/first week of life.

questions.text: Below is an X-ray of an infant with cyanotic heart diease. Which is not a finding seen here?
questions.solution:
Cyanosis and boot-shaped heart (cœur en sabot in French) points towards tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and the atrial septal defect is not a finding seen in TOF.

Clinical findings in TOF:

  • Right ventricular hypertrophy causing left anterior hemithorax bulge. 
  • Single S2 or soft P2 because of the stenotic pulmonary valve 
  • Systolic thrill in the left sternal border in 3rd and 4th parasternal spaces.
  • The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.
  • There is a loud and harsh systolic murmur due to the right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction. It becomes louder, longer, and harsher as obstruction increases in severity from mild to moderate. 
  • However in severe obstruction, especially during tet spell, the murmur becomes less prominent as the blood is shunted towards the aortic valve and not through RVOT. 

X-Ray in TOF showing boot shaped heart:

Acyanotic/pink tetralogy of Fallot: This occurs when obstruction to the right ventricular outflow is mild to moderate. The blood would flow more through the mildly obstructed RVOT and less through the VSD. Hence, there is less cyanosis.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-month-old blue baby to your pediatric clinic for the first time. Neonatal records were not available but the mother says that the X-ray of the baby looked like that of a shoe. Which of the following wouldn't you expect in this baby?

choices.text: Large "a" waves in jugular venous pulse

questions.solution:
The given history of the shoe (boot) shaped heart in cyanotic baby is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot and cardiomegaly is not a part of TOF presentation. 

In the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), we see concentric right ventricular hypertrophy without cardiac enlargement. It is because of pulmonary stenosis (PS) and the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Any build-up of pressure in the right ventricle due to PS is released through VSD to the left ventricle.

Option A: P2 is of low intensity and soft because the right ventricular outflow obstruction results in reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

Option B: The aortic root usually appears large because it overrides (straddling) the VSD, allowing deoxygenated blood shunted from the right ventricle mixed with blood from the left ventricle to exit the heart.

Option D: The large 'a' wave in the jugular pulse is a reflection of the forceful contraction of the right atrium at the end of diastole as there is reduced distensibility of the hypertrophic right ventricle.

questions.text: A primary school teacher notices a peculiar behavior in one of her pupils. Whenever he plays with his friends, she notices that her fingers and lips turn blue. The child then squats for sometime after which he feels better. Which of the following does not occur during squatting?

choices.text: It increases  the systemic vascular resistance
It increases the magnitude of right-to-left shunt
Leads to trapping of deoxygenated blood in lower limbs

questions.solution:
Squatting decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt in a child with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) .

The child feels comfortable while squatting due to two compensatory mechanisms:

  • Increasing systemic vascular resistance and, thus, decreasing the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD). Therefore, more blood goes to the lungs for oxygenation.
  • Trapping deoxygenated venous blood in the lower limbs.

questions.text: While waiting for corrective open-heart surgery, you decide to manage a case of tet spells medically. Which of the following drugs would worsen the cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Isoprenaline/isoproterenol should be avoided in tet or hypercyanotic spells. It will cause a decrease in total peripheral resistance (TPR) or systemic vascular resistance (SVR). So, more blood leaves the left ventricle leading to the increased right to left shunt. This results in the worsening of right ventricular outflow and causes worsening of cyanosis and the symptoms.

Treatment of hypercyanotic spell involves placing child in knee–chest position (or squatting), and use of:

  • oxygen
  • morphine - sedates the patient
  • sodium bicarbonate - to counteract metabolic acidosis that develops when arterial Po2 <40 mmHg 
  • alpha-agonists (phenylephrine)- vasopressor used in severe cases
  • beta-blockers (propranolol)- improves resting saturation and decreases the frequency of spells.

Drugs that increase SVR, such as IV phenylephrine (alpha-1 agonist) or propranolol (non-selective beta-antagonist/beta-2 block), can improve right ventricular outflow, decrease the right-to-left shunt, and improve the symptoms. This is same principle as squatting.

questions.text: Blalock-Taussig shunt is done between_________.
questions.solution:
Blalock–Taussig shunt is done between subclavian artery to pulmonary artery

Name of the surgery  Connects
Blalock–Taussig shunt (BS) Subclavian artery to pulmonary artery
Waterston's shunt (WA) Ascending aorta to right pulmonary artery
Pott's shunt (PD) Descending aorta to  pulmonary artery

Blalock–Taussig shunt is currently the most common aortopulmonary shunt procedure and consists of a Gore-Tex conduit.

Sometimes, the shunt is brought directly from the ascending aorta to the main pulmonary artery; in this case, it is called the central shunt.


Corrective open-heart surgery performed in critically ill newborns and early infancy is the preferred surgical treatment now.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the pentalogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
Pentalogy of Fallot consists of 

  • Tetralogy of Fallot: Ventricular septal defect + Pulmonic stenosis + Overriding of the aorta + Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Atrial septal defect

questions.text: An adolescent who is a known case of VSD is brought by his parents with complaints of breathlessness on exertion which is gradually progressive, bluish discoloration, and swelling of toes and fingers. Investigations showed features suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following is not a part of the condition?
questions.solution:
Given clinical scenario along with the development of pulmonary hypertension is seen in Eisenmenger’s syndrome and predominant right to left shunt (not left to right shunt) is seen here.

Gradual onset of cyanosis, dyspnoea, fatigue, and in later stages, heart failure, chest pain, headaches, syncope, and hemoptysis in a setting of congenital acyanotic heart disease, are signs and symptoms of Eisenmenger’s syndrome.

Reversal of the shunt at the level of atria/ventricles/patent ductus arteriosus due to irreversible pulmonary vascular obstructive changes is defined as Eisenmenger’s syndrome.

Features of pulmonary hypertension in Eisenmenger physiology: Right ventricular heave, narrow split S 2 with a loud pulmonic component.

Chest X-ray showing prominent pulmonary artery and right ventricle, peripheral pruning of pulmonary vessels.

ECG shows features of right ventricular hypertrophy, with spiked P waves.

Treatment: Calcium channel blockers, prostacyclin, and it's analog treprostinil and lung transplantation.

questions.text: The most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection is _________.
questions.solution:
The most common type of total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) is supracardiac.

In TAPVC, pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly.

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior venacava or left innominate vein.
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

questions.text: A neonate was noted to have cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Chest x-ray revealed a snowman appearance of the cardiac silhouette. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Snowman's appearance on the chest X-ray image is classically seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC).

The supracardiac variant can classically depict a snowman appearance/figure of 8/cottage loaf heart on the frontal chest radiograph.

The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on the top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

The image given above shows a snowman or figure-8 configuration. Cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity are evident.

questions.text: You are examining a week-old male infant who was severely cyanotic at birth in the post-operative ward. He has undergone balloon atrial septostomy following prostaglandin E1 administration. Post-surgery there was a marked improvement in cyanosis. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
Cyanosis at birth, prostagladin E1 administration, and septostomy to improve oxygenation are typical features of transposition of great vessels (TGA).

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood which can occur:

  • At atrial level: Through atrial septal defect (ASD)
  • At ventricle level: Through ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • At great vessel level: Through patent ductus arteriosus

Chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic “egg-on-string appearance”), and normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. The narrow pedicle of the heart is because of the malposition of the great vessels.

Treatment: Here, prostaglandin E1 administration and septostomy help initial stabilization by creating a communication between the right and left atria, thereby facilitating the mixing of systemic and pulmonary circulations.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with bipolar disorder on lithium therapy expresses intent to conceive. She must be advised to stop the drug due to the risk of development of which of the following conditions in the fetus?
questions.solution:
She must be asked to stop the intake of lithium as it can cause an Ebstein anomaly in the newborn.

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets.

Lithium can also cause macrocephaly as a teratogenic effect.

questions.text: Akshay, a high schooler presents to you with swelling of fingers and toes. He said he gets palpitations while he is exercising and even when he hangs out with friends. An X-Ray of the patient is given below.  ECG showed the presence of delta waves. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Ebstein's anomaly.

The presence of clubbing and a box-shaped heart on chest X-Ray in the given case is suggestive of Ebstein’s anomaly. Clubbing develops secondary to cyanosis as ebstein's anomaly is a right to left shunt. Delta wave is observed in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. WPW and supraventricular tachycardia causing palpitations can be seen in association with Ebstein’s anomaly.

questions.text: In a 13-year-old child with Ebstein's anomaly, echocardiography would likely reveal:
questions.solution:
Tricuspid regurgitation would be seen in a child with an Ebstein anomaly.

Mild cases develop cyanosis during adolescence or early adulthood. In severe cases, cyanosis manifests at birth. 

Ebstein anomaly is characterized by the downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which results in a thin-walled, low-pressure, “atrialized” segment of the right ventricle due to the anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets.

In Ebstein's, tricuspid valve tissue is dysplastic and results in tricuspid regurgitation.

The right ventricle is hypoplastic, which leads to decreased pulmonary outflow and there will be functional pulmonary atresia. As a result, blood shunts through the foramen ovale/atrial septal defect (ASD) results in cyanosis at birth.

Himalayan P wave (amplitude > 5 mm) is associated with tricuspid atresia, Ebstein anomaly, and combined tricuspid and pulmonary stenosis, where they indicate a dilated right atrium. Wolff–Parkinson–White syndrome (WPW) and supraventricular tachycardia may be present in Ebstein anomaly.

Note:

In Ebstein anomaly, the malformed tricuspid valve is usually regurgitant, but may rarely be stenotic.

questions.text: A cyanotic newborn is suspected of having congenital heart disease. He has an increased left ventricular impulse and a holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border. ECG shows left axis deviation and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical cyanosis in combination with left-axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) noted on the electrocardiogram distinguishes tricuspid atresia from most other cyanotic heart lesions.

Other points in favor:

  • Increased left ventricular impulse (in contrast to most other causes of cyanotic heart disease, in which an increased right ventricular impulse).
  • Holosystolic murmurs audible along the left sternal border (due to associated ventricular septal defect).

Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of the tricuspid valve. So, blood cannot flow directly from the right atrium to the right ventricle, and the following associated defects are necessary for survival:

  • Patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect: for the flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium
  • Ventricular septal defect: for the flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle
  • There is a hypoplastic right ventricle.

Option B and D: Truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot and - The ECG demonstrates right axis deviation (RAD) and evidence of RVH.

Option A: Transposition of great arteries- ECG is usually normal, showing the neonatal right-sided dominant pattern.

questions.text: You are examining a case of cyanosis in NICU as a resident. Which of the following cardiac features would make the diagnosis of tricuspid atresia unlikely?
questions.solution:
Left ventricular hypoplasia would make the diagnosis unlikely as right ventricular hypoplasia is seen in tricuspid atresia.

Other features of tricuspid atresia:

  • An increased left ventricular impulse is noted in contrast to an increased right ventricular impulse seen in most other cyanotic diseases.
  • A VSD holosystolic murmur is audible along the left sternal border.
  • The second heart sound (S2) is usually single.
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy and left axis deviation on ECG.
  • Tall, peaked P waves on lead II known as Himalayan P waves which are suggestive of an enlarged right atrium.

questions.text:
Which of the following cases could develop recurrent infections due to pulmonary congestion?

(1) A 12-year-old ventricular septal defect

(2) Tetrology of Fallot in a 3-year-old child 

(3) A toddler with tricuspid atresia.

(4) A 17-year-old with an atrial septal defect on echocardiogram.
questions.solution:
Patients with atrial and ventricular septal defects have increased pulmonary blood flow. This results in recurrent pulmonary infection due to congestion in the lungs.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) and tricuspid atresia (TA) are associated with reduced pulmonary blood flow (oligemic lung fields). They do not cause pulmonary congestion and do not predispose to infections.

Reduced pulmonary blood flow is due to

  • Right ventricular outflow obstruction in tetralogy of Fallot
  • Right ventricular inflow obstruction in tricuspid atresia


Cyanotic congenital heart diseases (CCHD) with decreased and increased pulmonary blood flow:

Decreased pulmonary blood flow Increased pulmonary blood flow

Tetrology of Fallot

Pulmonary atresia

Ebstein's anomaly

Tricuspid atresia with an intact ventricular septum

Transposition of the great vessels with VSD and pulmonary stenosis

Transposition of the great vessels with VSD or PDA

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC)

questions.text: A cyanotic baby at the 8th hour of life is being evaluated in NICU. Pulse oximetry shows 80 % not improving with 100 % O2. Records show that continuous machinery murmur was heard at birth but not anymore. Which of the following can be done?
questions.solution:
This baby has a cyanotic congenital heart disease that is dependent on a patent ductus arteriosus. Prostaglandin E1 infusion prevents the closure of PDA in term neonates with duct-dependent congenital heart disease (CHD).

Cyanosis failing to improve with 100% oxygen suggests an underlying cyanotic CHD.

Functional closure of the PDA occurs soon after birth, usually within first week of life.

The open PDA acted as a conduit between systemic and pulmonary circulations, thereby preventing the onset of cyanosis.

Upon its closure, cyanosis manifested in the baby as the blood could not be pumped into the lungs for oxygenation. Deoxygenated blood is being shunted into the systemic circulation after the closure of PDA. Hence, you should maintain the patency of the duct with PGE1 infusion until surgery can be done.

Duct-dependent lesions: Anomalies, in a newborn with CHD, which are dependent on the patency of ductus arteriosus for survival.

  • Right-sided lesions (Tetralogy of Fallot, PA/PS) cannot pump blood to the lungs. These patients are dependent on an open PDA for pulmonary circulation.
  • Left-sided lesions (Hypoplastic left heart syndrome, Aortic stenosis, Coarctation of aorta) cannot pump blood into the systemic circulation. These patients are dependent on open PDA for systemic circulation.

Indomethacin causes the closure of PDA. This leads to loss of either pulmonary or systemic circulation, eventually causing death. Therefore, indomethacin is contraindicated in duct-dependent CHDs.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray shows a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette which is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot.

The boot-shaped (coeur en sabot) cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields appear relatively clear due to reduced pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries, or both. 

In Ebsteins's anomaly (Option D) box-shaped heart is seen.

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest x-ray image?
questions.solution:
The given chest x-ray shows 'coeur-en-sabot' or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

The characteristic silhouette is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries and the aorta is usually enlarged. 

The image below describes the likeness of the cardiac silhouette to a boot: 

TOF is cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta)
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. In mild degrees, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibular hypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe degrees, pulmonary blood flow predominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presents with cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period.

Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterised by hyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initially awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to a prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.

Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve the dyspneic episode after which the child is able to resume the activity.

questions.text: Of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest x-ray except:
questions.solution:
The given chest x-ray shows an egg-on-string appearance seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). Enlargement of the left atrium is seen in TGA, not the right atrium.

The reason for left atrial enlargement is due to increased pulmonary blood flow.

TGA is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. This abnormal configuration leads to a narrow vascular pedicle.

As pulmonary vascular resistance drops during the first few days of life, blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature is increased. There is also elevated pulmonary venous pressure seen in TGA, especially in infants with an intact interventricular septum.

The globular (egg) appearance of the heart due to abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and the narrow superior mediastinum (string) result in the classical egg-on-string appearance.

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers.

Early management includes an immediate infusion of prostaglandin E1 which keeps the ductus arteriosus patent for improving oxygenation. Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy is a palliative catheter-based intervention that can be done to improve the hypoxic state before definitive surgery. The procedure creates an opening in the atrial septum which allows better inter-circulatory mixing of the blood. Jatene arterial switch procedure is the definitive surgery. 

Most infants with TGA do not survive till adulthood without corrective surgery.

questions.text: Below is the chest X-ray image obtained for a neonate on day 7 of life who developed heart failure later​. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic "egg on end" appearance on this chest X-ray image is seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). 

In the chest X-ray image, cardiomegaly with narrow mediastinum gives rise to the classic “egg-shaped heart.” The superior mediastinum appears narrow due to the anteroposterior relationship of the transposed great vessels and the radiologic absence of the thymus.

TGA is the most specific heart disease in the infant of a diabetic mother.

TGA is associated with uncontrolled phenylketonuria (PKU) in mother.
